dataset.title: City of Seattle a comparison of three non-fire slash treatments in the Abies amabilis zone of the Cedar River Municipal Watershed, Washington, USA, 2008 - 2012

creator.organizationName: City of Seattle, Seattle Public Utilities

abstract.para: Treatment effects on slash in young (< 50 years old) Abies amabilis stands were assessed for multiple management objectives. Assessment included measuring fuelbed characteristics and vegetation cover using line intersect transects before and after treatment. Three treatments were applied: (1) masticating using a “walking” excavator (Spyder) with a rotating mulching head, (2) lopping and piling using hand crews, and (3) cable yarding. Management objectives listed in order of importance were: (1) allow development of understory vegetation unimpeded by slash accumulation, (2) maintain forage for wildlife, especially deer and elk that is free from slash, (3) allow for wildlife habitat or travel corridors through restoration thinning areas and (4) reduce fire hazard by reducing fuel loading in key areas. Fire behavior was modeled in BehavePlus 4.0. Preliminary results show that lopping and piling surface fuels is effective at meeting the first three management objectives, and that mastication is effective at meeting the last two management objectives. Cable yarding might meet the objectives when the slash is green, directionally felled and of merchantable size.

contact.organizationName: City of Seattle, Seattle Public Utilities

description.para: The experiment was designed as a randomized complete block. The variable we were interested in exploring through the use of blocking was fuel loading. Our goal was to block along a gradient of fuel loading, from light to heavy.
Vegetation analysis was performed along two transects in each treatment block.
For detailed methods discussion see attached pdf files

personnel.organizationName: City of Seattle, Seattle Public Utilities

abstract.para: Restoration thinning was conducted between years 2000 and 2013 in upland areas where needed in densely stocked, young, second-growth stands (generally less than 30 years old) to reduce competition, improve understory vigor and diversity, and adjust species composition to increase diversity. The stands that received highest priority for restoration thinning were those that: (1) are most over-stocked, based on age, species, and site characteristics; (2) exhibit signs of severe competition and stress and are determined to be at greatest risk of causing catastrophic damage; and (3) have the greatest potential for beneficial results. The decision regarding the density of leave trees was made on a site-specific basis. The City conducted a total of 10,041 acres of restoration thinning.

dataTable.entityDescription: size and decay of slash by species pre treatment

codeDefinition.definition: All bark is intact. All but the smallest twigs are present. Old needles probably still present. Hard when kicked
Some bark is missing, as are many of the smaller branches. No old needles still on branches. Hard when kicked
Most of the bark is missing and most of the branches < 1 in. in diameter also missing. Still hard when kicked

Looks like a class 3 log but the sapwood is rotten. Sounds hollow when kicked and you can probably remove wood from the outside with your boot. Pronounced sagging if suspended for even moderate distances.
Entire log in contact with the ground. Easy to kick apart but most of the piece is above the general level of the adjacent ground

dataTable.entityDescription: size and decay of slash by species post treatment

codeDefinition.definition: All bark is intact. All but the smallest twigs are present. Old needles probably still present. Hard when kicked
Some bark is missing, as are many of the smaller branches. No old needles still on branches. Hard when kicked
Most of the bark is missing and most of the branches < 1 in. in diameter also missing. Still hard when kicked

Looks like a class 3 log but the sapwood is rotten. Sounds hollow when kicked and you can probably remove wood from the outside with your boot. Pronounced sagging if suspended for even moderate distances.
Entire log in contact with the ground. Easy to kick apart but most of the piece is above the general level of the adjacent ground
